content.description: Starting on the north face of the pinnacle near the right corner, climb up a right-sloping crack to a large ledge. Continue up the outside corner to the top. Height related crux. This climb is easier for taller people.
content.protection: There is no protection above the ledge
content.location: On the north face of the free standing pinnacle (the face directly opposite the main cliff)

content.description:
Diagonal up right on easy rock to the base of a short left facing corner (Var. 1, Var. 2) Follow the inside corner to the top. There are photos of people standing on top dating from the early 20th  century. 

  Var. 1 (Unnamed) 5.5   Traverse right to the south side of the pinnacle, mantle up to a ledge and then continue up to the top. 

  Var. 2  Wayworn 5.7   FA?: Alex Catlin May 1986   Climb the face to the left of the corner, without using the corner.
content.protection: Anchoring possibilities at the top are sparse. Consider how you are going to get down. In the past, after leading to the top, I've had my belayer ground anchor to one of the trees at the base. Drape the rope over the top and rappel off the opposite side.
content.location: Start on the the west side of the free standing pinnacle at the base of Devil's Chute.

content.description:
Starting in the center of the east face of the pinnacle, climb straight up the face until you reach a horizontal crack that cuts the whole face and a nitch in the northeast corner (Var. 1). Climb the corner to the top. 

  Var 1 Run Away 5.8 

  Finger traverse left around the corner to join South Way.
content.location: East face of the free standing pinnicle

content.description:
10 ft or so to the right of 'knees', climb up the short featured face, moving right towards a triangle shaped pocket. climb up to a horizontal crack, traverse right on the crack, and up the arete, to a very juggy finish 

  (note, i do not intend to take any credit for 'knees' or 'triangle'.  I am almost certain that I'm not the first ascender of either of these routes, but beta for these areas is so hard to come by, I think its time some of these routes were posted.)
content.protection: make sure to bring small wires

content.description: Start on the south face directly below the thin crack that splits the overhang. Face climb straight up and follow the thin crack through the overhang. Traverse left and mantle to another ledge and then climb up left to the top.
content.protection:
There are no anchors on the top surface. Consider dropping a rope and having your belayer make a ground anchor on the opposite side of the pinnacle and you can belay from the top.  

 Chris P suggested "There is an old bolt that seems more or less solid." (11/2019)

 This single bolt is on the face near the top of "South Way". It is a 1/2" carbon steel bolt screwed into a self drilling expansion anchor. It was placed sometime in the mid-1980s as part of an anchor to do a Tyrolean traverse back to the main cliff.  So, use at your own risk.
content.location: South side of the free standing pinnacle (Chimney Rock)

content.description:
Climb the open book until you reach a point just below the roof. Step right (loose block) and up a groove to the right of the first roof. Finish through the final roof above or traverse right and up on easier rock.  

  In the 1980s we found two ancient rusty pitons on this route. For identification purposes and because we had little hard information we began to give some of these routes “working names” until we could learn more. It’s amusing to see how some of our “working names” have stuck and were adopted. “That bolted route” became “Bolted 5.9” on the Chin. “That route with the rusty pins” became “Rusty Pins 5.8” out at the Tower Area.
content.protection: Bring a standard trad rack. If the two rusty pins are still there, they are useless.
content.location: Behind the free standing pinnacle is a low angle wall followed by an alcove. Start 10' to the right of the alcove, at a wide open book with a 8" tree at its base and a 3' roof about halfway up.

content.description: Climb the openbook then through the overhang at the crack. Continue up and right to a brush filled gully (loose rock). Finish up the smooth arete to the left of the gully.
content.location: Start at an open book with an overhang half way up about 5' right of "Rusty Pins". The overhang is split on the left side by a 1" crack. At the base of open book is a 6' block

content.description:
Pretty fun short little climb, starts in the corner in the gully just past (to the right) the freestanding tower, to the right of a small tree. 

  Climb 20 ft up the corner, short pumpy hand traverse to the right onto the arete.  Follow on either side of the arete, up and over the small roof. Uou could smear for days on this rock, so grippy and fresh!
content.protection: didnt take much note of that :(
content.location: on the right hip.  From the observation tower at the top of the tower (duh) trail.  Head south towards the towards the cliffs.  Follow the steep walled gully down and to left.  Follow the base of the wall past the freestanding tower.

content.description:
Called the “Left Hip/Left Leg” on Sleeping Giant maps, the cliff at the Tower Area faces southeast, is up to 50' high in places and several hundred feet long.  

  Outstanding features are the stone tower (built by WPA in the 1930's), a free standing spire (Chimney Rock) at the base of the cliff, Deadman's Cave (AKA  Abraham's Cave) and “Devil’s Chute” which provides access from the top of the cliff. 

  Rock is typical Connecticut traprock but seems more abrasive than Ragged Mountain or Pinnacle. Ancient rusted pitons give evidence that climbing has been going on here for a long time.
